review.title: Improved Mean and Variance Approximations for Belief Net Responses via Network Doubling
review.abstract: A Bayesian belief network models a joint distribution with an directed acyclic graph representing dependencies among variables and network parameters characterizing conditional distributions. The parameters are viewed as random variables to quantify uncertainty about their values. Belief nets are used to compute responses to queries; i.e., conditional probabilities of interest. A query is a function of the parameters, hence a random variable. Van Allen et al. (2001, 2008) showed how to quantify uncertainty about a query via a delta method approximation of its variance. We develop more accurate approximations for both query mean and variance. The key idea is to extend the query mean approximation to a "doubled network" involving two independent replicates. Our method assumes complete data and can be applied to discrete, continuous, and hybrid networks (provided discrete variables have only discrete parents). We analyze several improvements, and provide empirical studies to demonstrate their effectiveness.

sections.heading: 6 COMPUTATIONAL ISSUES
sections.text: Inference in Bayes networks is generally an NPcomplete problem (Cooper, 1990). Alarm 108, for example, is the complexity of the variable elimination algorithm (VE) O (dr), where d is an upper limit on the number of values a variable can assume, and r is an upper limit on the size of a factor generated by the VE algorithm (Koller and Friedman, 2008). Doubling the network essentially uses the same technique to calculate a variance as used to evaluate a query, resulting in corresponding computational complexity. Doubled CP tables are larger (squared number of rows and columns), increasing the computational complexity from VE to O (d2r). The Delta method retains O (dr) complexity (Van Allen et al., 2008), so the double CP table is typically faster in large networks.

This technique uses the Cooper-Herskovits formula (5) to approximate the query average.This theory also provides convergence rates for the approximations. • Numerical comparisons of network duplication and delta methods show superior accuracy of the former methods in simple networks. • Customizations to improve accuracy motivated by asymptotic theory for discrete networks. This theory also provides convergence rates for the approximations. • Numerical comparisons of network duplication and delta methods show superior accuracy of the former methods in simple networks. We do not recommend replacing network duplications in all applications.
